msgSnippet: ... Pick a class from the library.  I d start with the utility classes, the lower-level calls.  Write tests for the public and protected methods in those

From: Joi Ellis <joi@...>

On Tue, 23 Jan 2001, Peter Bismuti wrote:

> 
> I've been assigned to write JUnit tests for a preexisting library for my company and I'm having trouble getting it off the ground.  It seems to me that this requires a deep level of understanding how the code works, how else can you come up with a set of meaningful tests?  
> 
> Besides that, I'm having trouble coming up with ideas of tests to write.  For example, there is a class called Trace that is used for debugging.  It has methods that you call at the beginning and end of each subroutine in your code to mark it.  How could you possibly write a test for this?  Others redirect output, etc, etc.  
> 
> Any ideas how I can get this project off the ground?  Any methodology for generating tests?  

Pick a class from the library.  I'd start with the utility classes, the
lower-level calls.  Write tests for the public and protected methods in those
classes.  Work your way from the inside out.  As you progress you'll be able
to see structure to the package (hopefully!)

For trace, I'd want to know more about how trace works.  I suppose it sends
output to System.print?  You could try redirecting System.print with your
own subclass.

Here's an example of redirecting stdout and stderr:

http://developer.java.sun.com/developer/TechTips/1999/tt1021.html#tip2

Now, subclass OutputStream and provide your own print methods which simply
stuff the printed output into something like a Vector.  Now run your test
method, and Assert that the vector contains the Strings you expect it to
contain given what you did with trace's calls.
